Problem:
Consider a scenario where a function \\( z(t) = e^{tA}z_0 \\) describes the evolution of a variable vector \\( z \\) through a linear transformation system in time \\( t \\), where \\( A \\) is a constant matrix. Another function \\( w(z) = Cz \\), where \\( C \\) is also a constant matrix, applies another linear transformation at an arbitrary time.

If the function \\( w(z) \\) is applied to a vector \\( z_0 \\) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve under the function \\( z(t) = e^{tA}z_0 \\) without further intervention, will the vector \\( z(T) \\) at t = T be the same as if \\( z_0 \\) was directly evolved to t = T under the function without the application of \\( w(z) \\)?
Explanation: Applying \\( w(z) \\) alters the initial state to \\( w(z_0) = Cz_0 \\). The evolution of \\( z(t) \\) from this new initial state, \\( e^{tA}(Cz_0) \\), generally differs from \\( e^{tA}z_0 \\) due to the presence of multiplication by \\( C \\), thus affecting the trajectory unless \\( C \\) commutes with \\( e^{tA} \\).
